review_blob: *12 oz. bottle* Look: Black body, small mocha head. Smell: German chocolate cake, roasted malts hints of coffee bean, smells rich. Taste: Bitter chocolate, burnt malts, cherry pit, espresso, pine bitterness finishes. Feel: Medium smooth body, tight carbonation. Overall: This is pretty solid. Very decent stout. Not very complex yet still enjoyable. The aroma is superior to the flavor (IMO). This isnt offensive in any way. For it being 8.5%, this drinks like more like a 6% beer. Slightly above the middle of the road stouts. This brew is worthy.
beer_name: Left Coast Voo Doo American Stout

review_blob: *12 oz. bottle* Look: Dense dark brown body with velvet hues. 1/2 finger off white head. Smell: Chocolate, roasted grains, slight molasses, char notes a little spice, hints of coffee beans. Taste: Roasted malts, smooth chocolate, coffee beans, with a subtle touch of vanilla, charred wood, hints of red apple skin, dry and bitter finish. Feel: Light body, intense carbonation. Overall: This stout is clean. For it being a Belgian style stout, I thought there would be a little more yeasty funk to it. The flavors are nice yet are delicate, not in your face stout quality. The carbonation pulls away some of the subtle flavors that are enjoyable. The body could be more bold as well. This is still solid, well polished and well crafted. This just doesnt scream "World Class" to me. This brew is worthy.

*12 oz. bottle* Look: Dark copper body, 1/2 finger had that turned to a lacing around my glass. Smell: Sugar coated plums, alcohol, toasted bread, berries, mild citrus, hint of spice. Taste: Brown sugar, sweet toasted malts, hint of dates, berries, alcohol, dry slight bitter finish. Feel: Medium-full body, active carbonation. Overall: Incredibly well balanced for it being 15% abv. I can say this isnt my favorite Barley Wine, yet it is close. This could use some aging to allow all the flavors to mature. It is a little hot for fresh consumption but it still is balanced. This brew is worthy.

*25.4 oz. bottle* Look: Black body with dark brown hues, 2 finger khaki head. Smell: Nutty, toffee, hints of chocolate, licorice, roasted malts, coffee in the back ground, spicy, smells sweet. Taste: Chocolate, toffee, hazelnuts, licorice, hints of cedar, peppermint astringency, bitter sweet dry finish, with coffee and raspberries in the aftertaste. Feel: Medium light body, active carbonation. Overall: This is a treat for sure. Its hoppy, its roasted, it has wood! This beer is all over the place. Yet it is extremely balanced. This turned out to be my favorite of the Ommegangs "GoT" releases. This brew is recommended while it is still around!
beer_name: Ommegang Game of Thrones #2 - Take the Black Stout

review_blob: *12 oz. bottle* Look: Sunset orange body, 1 finger white head. Smell: Very citrus (Oranges, lemon peel), toasted cracker sweetness, bit of mango and a touch of tropical flowers. Taste: Mango, oranges, grapefruit, flowers, earthy leafiness, papaya, very solid malt backbone, semi dry mild bitter finish. Feel: Medium smooth body, mediocre carbonation. Overall: This is solid and also very tasty. Im glad I tried this ale. This is balanced and enough hop flavor that it lands on what could be DIPA status. The bitter factor isnt offensive. A nice stepping stone in quality IPAs. If you like exotic fruits/flower flavors in your beer, this is a go to. This beer is recommended.

*11.2 oz. bottle* Look: Nice golden shade of blonde, 1 finger white soapy head. Smell: Citrus, grassy, yeast, hints of fruits, doughy sweetness, herbal notes. Taste: Citrus, grainy, honey dough, lighter fruits, spice, herbal aftertaste, dry and nice sharp bitter finish. Feel: Medium-light smooth body, tight fizzy carbonation. Overall: This beer is great. You have the Tripel components and also hoppy notes as well. Each hop plays its role well. Nice Spicy/Herbal Resin hops aftertaste. That was blanketed by first a honey dough and sugar malt sweetness. Citric hops are in here too. They grab the tip of the tongue and say "How do you do?". Plus the 9% abv is very well masked. If you like generously hopped ales and Tripels, you will be in Belgian nirvana. This brew is Recommended.

*12 oz. bottle* Look: Hazy golden blonde body, 1 1/2 finger white soapy head. Smell: Tart citrus, spices, hay, yeasty, hints of earthy quality tobacco, mild funk. Taste: Tart citrus (Lemon peel) wheat and oats, honey, hint of a fruit (pear), sweet and dry and slightly sour. Feel: Medium-light body, very active carbonation. Overall: This is very delicious. One of the prime examples of the style. I have no problem drinking a four pack of this all Summer/Fall long. For it being almost 8% it isnt detectable. This brew is recommended.

*12 oz. bottle* Look: Nice orange shade of amber body, 2 1/2 finger white frothy head. Smell: Toasted malts, mild citrus, spices, faint caramel sweetness, mild herbal qualities. Taste: toasted oats, caramel, coriander, touch of a ripe banana, spicy yeast, mildly nutty, honey flavor not the sugary sweetness, dry finish. Feel: Light body, tight carbonation. Overall: This ale is very light on the palate for being 6.5% I like how all the flavors in what reminds me of a hearty bowl of Honey Nut Cheerios, with a side order of bananas served with orange juice. There is a nice hop bite that sets up the right amount of bitterness to make this beer crisp. This is recommended.

*12 oz. bottle* Look: Cloudy Straw yellow body, nice frothy white head. Smell: Strong wheat grains, tangerines, spices, yeast. Taste: Oranges, fresh grains, spicy, peppery, hint of fresh lemon zest, sweet, dry slightly bitter and refreshing. Feel: Light body, poppy carbonation. Overall: I found my next Summers ale. This is indeed is a well crafted Witbier, The flavor profile is robust and makes itself known. The light body and citrus notes make this beer very easy to consume. Flavorful and refreshing, this brew is recommended.

*11.2 oz. bottle* Look: Very dark ruby red body, off-white lacey ring around my glass. Smell: Strong notes of toffee, dark red fruits, licorice, well rounded vanilla, faint hint of cocoa. Taste: Toffee, slight cherry, licorice, bitter cocoa, subtle hints of spice, toasted nuts, vanilla, well balanced dryness that finishes slight bitter. Feel: Medium-light body, poppy carbonation. Overall: Very tasty and to the point. I can see why this is called Celebrator. At nearly 7%abv, there is a lot going on. The flavors are pronounced yet are seem individual other than just being a mess in a glass. The dryness leaves you wanting more. This is recommended.

*25.4 oz. Bottle* Look: Ruby red body in the sun, 1 finger head that turned into just an off white ring around my goblet. Smell: Huge spices, fruity yeast notes, sweet malts, candied sugar. Taste: Spices, yeast characters, maple in the after taste, candied sugar, fruity tartness like some aged cherries, vegetable starchiness. There is some heat to this, but Im thinking it is a spice heat (cinnamon, nutmeg) and not an Alcoholic heat. There is a modest hop bitterness that helps cut the malty sweetness. Feel: Full smooth body, gentle carbonation. Overall: Nice twist on the "Pumpkin" ale style. Make a Belgian style yam ale. This brew is very dangerous. If it werent for the spices, there would be no warmth at all. Goes down smooth and tasty. This is easily recommended.

*25.4 oz. bottle March 1st. date* Look: Brilliant golden honey amber, what was a 1 finger white head turned into a white ring around my glass. Smell: Bourbon, wet hay, spicy, honey graham crackers, faint alcohol, subtle flowers. Taste: Like the aroma yet much richer. Vanilla, subtle hints of coconut, nice fruity pear esters shine through the overall bourbon characteristics, nice hints of flowers in there with a honey wheat bread sweetness, no alcohol heat or flavor is detected, lemon zest in there as well, there is a nice bitter bite to it as well. Feel: Medium-full body, tight active carbonation. Overall: Man, this ale is a hit for me. 11% ABV is not even a presence in the flavor, very devilishly. The malt sweetness gives a little to let you know it is a big beer. Im very impressed on how flavorful this ale is and yet it is delicate at the same time. A lovely combo Balanced and Dangerous! The bourbon isnt overdone and the Tripel components are just right. Recommended.

*12 oz. can* Look: Dark amber brown body, 1 finger off white head. Smell: Baked doughy malts, hints of citrus, faint wood, cooked assorted vegetables. Taste: Malty, some spice, cut grass, vegetables, bitter. Feel: Medium body, par carbonation. Overall: This is weird. Sometime the flavor is ok. I wanted to like this but for the heart of me, I can not. Because I didnt like it fully, this is still worth a shot.
beer_name: Sly Fox Rte. 113 India Pale Ale

review_blob: *25.4 oz. bottle* Look: Solid black body with dark brown hues. 1 1/2 frothy mocha head. Smell: Tons of roasted malts, hints of vanilla and cocoa nibs, mild mushroom earthiness, no alcohol presence, very sweet like burnt marshmallows. Taste: Roasted malt, earthy spiciness (ginger, cinnamon) sweet honey molasses, on the acidic/ tart side, no alcohol is detectable, dry bitter finish with almost a burnt/ dead leaves aftertaste. Feel: Light/ oily on the palate, weird cola like carbonation. Overall: I hope the Album is as Jazzy as this stout is. The aroma I enjoyed and the flavor is different from the aroma. I really enjoy that aspect. This stout isnt just a "Roasted Coffee, Chocolate Milkshake" of an Imperial Stout. There is some earthy funk to it. I believe that is missing in stouts brewed today. The thing that made it miss the "Oh yeah" feeling was the mouth feel (My opinion anyway). For the amount of coca cola carbonation, I was expecting a more aggressive malt stickiness. Other than that I enjoyed this brew very much. This brew is recommended.

*12 oz. bottle* Look: beautiful burnt orange body, white ring around my glass. Smell: Tropical flowers, peaches, strong earthy character ( maybe some cedar sap), mild alcohol, mild mango, oranges, faint pineapple, instant tea in the background with some grainy sweetness. Taste: Floral, candy oranges, earth, dank, spice, resin, mango in the aftertaste, huge bitterness, and alcohol heat, dry as a bone. Feel: Medium body, par carbonation. Overall: Bam! The aroma is delightful. Fruits and Flowers that melted together with some Cedar bark. The taste is a bit sweet. Which is understandable, you need a lot of malt to carry the Hops of this caliber. The alcohol is a presence that warms the body. Winter Time TRIPA? This is on the sipping side. This is one of the driest IPAs Ive had so far. I dont know if its the alcohol or the hops. Any who, the high ABV just doesnt win the "Stellar" status for me. Maybe if these hops were used in a lower gravity IPA, I would enjoy this better. This brew is worthy.

*12 oz. bottle* Look: Dark brown almost red body, 1 finger off white soapy head. Smell: Caramel, toasted malts, faint fruit, hint of cocoa, a touch of spice. Taste: Sweet caramel, toasted malt, nutty, faint spice, finishes dry with a blend of chocolate and caramel in the aftertaste. Feel: Light smooth body, par carbonation. Overall: This porter is to the point. The aroma has more going on in it than the flavor. Not a bad thing. Sometimes I like it when a beer gets me thinking it is going to be one way with the aroma, and then changes lanes (Either good or bad). This drinks smooth and I could drink this pretty much all day. I like Robust and Roasted brews. But with all the other Porters out there this one is solid yet not adventurous. This brew is worthy.

*11.2 oz. bottle* Look: Black body with a 1/2 mocha head. Smell: Full creamy molasses, mild bitter coffee, hints of pine oil, mild dough, alcohol, chocolate, oats and spices. Taste: Molasses, cookie dough, burnt malts, sweet chocolate with hints of cocoa, cinnamon spice, hints of bacon? salty, bittersweet finish with a little acidity. Feel: Medium-full body, weird cola like carbonation. Overall: One of the weirdest Imperial Stouts Ive had. Some parts remind me of Night Stalker some parts of a spiced Danish with bacon. Salty spice flavors and hints of acidity in there as well. This isnt bad by all means, just different. Some parts of me says "This is world class". Some parts says.. otherwise. This shares a Love/ Hate relation on my taste buds. Thanks for warping my mind again Evil Twin. This Brew is worthy.
beer_name: Evil Twin Christmas Eve at a New York City Hotel Room (2011-)

review_blob: *16.9 oz.* Look: Very dark brown almost black body with brown hues, off white head. Smell: Deep roasted malts, coffee, chocolate sweetness, mild smoke, faint spice, fruity character almost orange peel. Taste: Nice chocolate, roasted malts that give to coffee (Not burnt coffee, but almost burnt.), sweet malts, a bitter earthy finish. Feel: Full body, tight fizzy carbonation, this time it fits like a fine Belgian ale. Overall: I dont know why I havent tried this before. This isnt the "Buckets full of Hops" that M.B.C. are used to contributing to their beers. This is tasty and also walks the thin line of being an Imperial Porter. Dont get me wrong about the hops. It doesnt lack them either. Like a fine Belgian beer, the hops arent in for flavoring. They are used for the dryness of the flavor and bitterness to cut the sweetness ( which does a fine job at that). This beer is rock solid. I wish I had another bottle that is how much I enjoyed this beer. This is Recommended.

* Growler* Look: Beautiful honey amber body with 1/2 finger slightly off white head. Smell: Mango, spice, floral, mild tropical pineapple, dank lemon zest, mild astringency, some spruce in the background. Taste: Red papaya, mild passion fruit, mild mango, flowers, spice, mild grapefruit rind, peppermint, herbal tea, resin, bready malt, strong clean bitter finish with a leafy/ tobacco aftertaste. Feel: Medium-light body, active carbonation. Overall: If this is Hop Wallops replacement.. Count me excited. Mosaic & Citra make weird love in this beer. I cant describe it. The flavors seem to have a bound with each other. I love Victory on how they can blend hop flavors evenly. If this is a DIPA, then it is one of the most drinkable DIPAs I have ever had. This can get you into trouble. The 8.7 ABV is not detectable. This is balanced, bitter, and enjoyable. This brew is Recommended.

* 16.9 oz. bottle* Look: Nice honey orange body, 3 finger white soapy head ( I must have poured aggressively). Smell: Dank citrus, hints of apricots, bready notes, lemon grass as warms and lavender, mild berries, and some astringency. Taste: Citrus rind, pine cones, mild aftertaste of apricots, spear mint, papaya, mild resin, subtle bitterness, semi-dry finish with a mellow wheat bread aftertaste. Feel: Light body, tight fizzy carbonation. Overall: This is less aggressive than Lunch. Yet I enjoy this one better than Lunch. Maine Beer Company make sure that the Hops are the showcase of their ales. Also M.B.C. is good at hiding their alcohol in all their IPAs. Like I said before about Hops. If you have a Hop Tooth, this is the brewery for you. The two things I have against M.B.C. (my opinion anyway), is the price tag and the mouth feel on their brews that Ive had so far. It is either Medium mediocre or Light mediocre. Nothing really to make the palate pop and say "I love this". Other than that I could drink their IPAs and Pales all week long. This brew is recommended.

* 16.9 oz. bottle* Look: Nice honey golden amber body, 1 finger white soapy head. Smell: Oranges and grapefruit on first whiff, tropical flowers, mild spruce sap in the background, nice hints of toasted wheat. Taste: Citrus fruits (tangerines and grapefruit) floral, pineapple, dank earthiness, herbs, resin, sweet bready malt, nice dose of bitterness, finishes dry with an aftertaste of spruce and citrus rind. Feel: Medium-light body, tight fizzy carbonation. Overall: This is hop forward. There is very little malt to balance but man is it easy to drink. Even though this is fresh, I still prefer MO over this. Call me a mad man, call me what you will. Dont get me wrong I love the aroma and Centennial in the flavor. I just feel that this is lacking a little bit from being insanely great. I still recommend this to any IPA die hard fanatics.

* 8.4 oz. can* Look: Nice dark amber/ reddish tint body, off white 1/4 finger off white head. Smell: Slammed with caramel covered berries, alcohol, faint lemon peel, cookie dough, toasted grains. Taste: Like the aroma but with less alcohol body, more of an alcohol/ hop dryness, warmth in the throat, the aftertaste is of toasted nuts and fruits covered in caramel. Feel: Medium-full smooth body, slightly par carbonation. Overall: The image that I get from this beer is to compete with another overly hopped "West Coast" Barley wine. Not going to mention names here. You can catch my drift here. This can was from Feb. 5th of this year so fresh hop flavors are out of the question. I do pick up some lemon/ grapefruit zest in the finish. I will admit it hides its 11.5 ABV very well. I just can not for a reason see the point of 8.4 oz. per can. Yet while I question the can size, I can recommend this ale for any well hopped Barley Wine lovers.

* 12 oz. Bottle* Look: Bright orange medium amber body, 1 finger slightly off white head. Smell: Spice, floral, almost a papaya/ mango fruitiness, mild herbal tea. Taste: Spicy, tropical fruits, floral, cedar, tea, resin, caramel sweetness, dry bittersweet finish with tropical fruits in after taste. Feel: Medium-light smooth body, crisp sharp carbonation. Overall: This brew wows me in the aftertaste. Picture opening a can of tropical fruit and just drinking the juice but it was filtered through cedar tree sap. I mean there isnt nothing offensive with this ale. Before the finish there is a hop resin flavor ( I like to call "Hop Cheese") bams the palate. I love Resin from Six Point, this is his younger more sessional brother. This is balanced and Recommended.

*12 oz. Bottle* Look: Golden amber body, small white head. Smell: Herbal, earthy, dense floral, vanilla sweetness. Taste: Candied oranges, marmalade, hints of cedar, floral, mild citric rind, doughy sweetness, alcohol, semi-dry bitter finish. Feel: Medium smooth body, active carbonation. Overall: One of the sweetest DIPAs Ive had. It is like a dessert IPA. Not a bad thing, I just need a sweet tooth to be able to enjoy all the qualities it offers. This brew is worthy.Earlier Rating: 9/15/2013 Total Score: 3.7*12 oz. Bottle* Look: Golden amber body, small white head. Smell: Herbal, earthy, dense floral, vanilla sweetness. Taste: Candied oranges, marmalade, hints of cedar, floral, mild citric rind, doughy sweetness, alcohol, semi-dry bitter finish. Feel: Medium smooth body, active carbonation. Overall: One of the sweetest DIPAs Ive had. It is like a dessert IPA. Not a bad thing, I just need a sweet tooth to be able to enjoy all the qualities it offers. This brew is worthy.

*12 oz. Bottle* Look: Nice Ruby red body, active carbonation, small off-white head. Smell: Tea, citrus, pineapple, little touch of berries. Taste: Citrus, hints of pine, little papaya, spice, dry bitter finish. Feel: Very light body, tight fizzy carbonation. Overall: This tastes like a flagship ale not a Seasonal Release. Maybe Im wrong, but that is what it comes off to me anyway. I love Centennial hop flavors so I dont mind this ale at all. It does lack something, maybe more fuller mouth feel or malt sweetness? Something that doesnt scream "Middle of the Road" IPA. I guess when it comes down to it, can I kill a sixer of this?.... Yes I can. Will I purchase this again? When I cant find a Fresh Batch of Hop Devil next Fall. This brew is Solid and Worthy.

*On tap Maxs* Look: Bright orange body, 1 1/2 finger white head. Smell: Fruits, straw grains, almost bubblegum, spice, slight banana. Taste: Follows the aroma with juicy fruits, honey wheat dough, spices, mild floral, very nice semi-dry fruity finish. Feel: Light soft body, very active carbonation. Overall: This one didnt knock me out of my socks but man it is tasty fresh. Very refreshing on a hot summer day or even as a nice after dinner treat. This one though I can enjoy anytime, the flavors are not offensive and is very easy to drink. Bless the Belgians for making beer an art form. This is recommended.

*On Tap Maxs* Look: Deep brass shade of orange body, 1 finger white head, lively carbonation. Smell: Grapefruit citrus, spice, cereal grains, faint earth. Taste: Citrus upfront, earth, nice malt sweetness, faint funk, semi dry bitter finishes with more grapefruit. Overall: Tiger stripes is right! That was all that was left in my pint glass when I finished. This is very drinkable and refreshing. Two qualities I love in my any kind of Pale Ale. I mean it doesnt have a "Wow" factor but it is so good fresh. This brew is worthy.

* 12 oz. bottle* Look: Dark murky brown almost red body, 1/2 finger off white head. Smell: Mild citrus fused with intense toasted grains, caramel sweetness, subtle earth notes. Taste: Spicy, mild citrus rind, wood, toasted grains, and a hint of pineapple?, sweet oak finishes with a smoky camp fire flavor. Bitter as an old man with no beer money. Feel: Medium-light body, active, almost harsh carbonation. Overall: I hate to say this but this ale is aggressive. This is not for everyone like the brewer said. Both hops and malts come full force and with the aggressive bitterness and also detectable alcohol bite. This beer will take your palate to a bar so it can purposely beat it with a stool. I dont have a problem slapping two bottles of this at anytime. But after two it might get a bit, tiresome. It is a liquid journey, just not down the alley I would prefer. This brew is worthy.

* 22 oz. Bomber* Look: Midnight black with a 1 finger deep mocha head. It looks like used diesel motor oil. Smell: Chocolate/ cocoa nibs, sweet molasses, burnt grains fused with coffee. Taste: Chocolate, roasted sweet malts, burnt coffee bitterness, cookie dough, espresso, vanilla/ chocolate as finishes. Feel: Medium body, mild soft carbonation. Overall: This reminds me of the Caravel Ice Cream Cake blended with my morning cup of espresso. Very smooth to the point its almost ridiculous. 11.5 that is not detectable. Drinkable beyond belief for such a big beer. Sweet and bitter. Im sure it isnt the best Imperial Stout brewed today, but it is pretty close. Recommended.

*On tap Maxs* Look: Nice shade of brass blonde, nice white lacing. Smell: Mellow tangerine with fresh grapefruit hanging in the background, faint alcohol, some grain sweetness. Taste: Citrus, nice herbal/ tobacco leaf, hint of resin, subtle malt sweetness, modest bitterness finishes clean. Feel: Medium-light body par carbonation. Overall: Hoppy goodness for sure. This brew sets juicy hop flavors to the front. Enough malt to entertain the hops on the palate. The alcohol is only present in the aroma, so this ale could get you in trouble. The modest bitterness is refreshing for a big beer like this. Is this an earthshattering DIPA? No, yet it holds its own in the West Coast Style. Recommended.

*On tap Maxs split with David* Look: Deep black body ruby hues. Smell: Tart green apples/dried cherries, spices, licorice, deep toasted wheat bread, some funk. Taste: Green apples, sweet malts, spice, on the tart side, some acidity, bourbon finish, some heat. Feel: Medium-full body, par carbonation. Overall: Im glad I had the chance to drink this. Very nice ale, but not much bourbon flavor except the finish is charred oak. I would recommend this to any Belgian Strong Ale lovers, like myself.

*22 oz. bomber* Look: Bright shade of orange, no head, active carbonation. Smell: Full of spices, leafy/ Earth tone, sweet caramel. Taste: Spices, caramel, mild acidity, finishes clean with more vanilla and caramel in the aftertaste, very moderate bitterness. Feel: Medium soft body, par carbonation. Overall: Very, very good pumpkin beer. Like the name says "Imperial PumKING". I mean the aroma tells you what youre in for. What gets me is this brew is balanced to perfection. Full on the palate sweet malts and spices are on the heavy side but not over the edge. Drinkability is off the charts. 8.6 % abv is not detectable. Recommended.

Look: Brass orange body, 1/2 finger white head. Smell: Tropical Flowers fused with fruits (like a womans perfume), citrus, tobacco and faint alcohol. Taste: Floral, citric rind, spicy, fruits, tobacco, strong bitterness, mild alcohol bite. Feel: Medium body, active carbonation. Overall: 17th reminds me of a certain other beer named Victory Hop Wallop. Nothing wrong with that though the malt sweetness is a bit brighter with Stone. All the flavors and aroma are the practically the same. I sipped this and Hop Wallop came to mind. The only thing that sets them apart is the bitterness and pilsner malt sweetness. Other than that this brew is worthy. Nothing earthshattering but still very solid.

Look: Black body, 1/2 finger head that quickly turned in to a mocha lacing. Smell: Chocolate, burnt coffee, licorice, spiciness. Taste: Roasted coffee, mild chocolate, cereal grain, bittersweet dry finish with chocolate in the aftertaste. Feel: Medium light creamy body, active carbonation. Overall: This is in short is a "to the point" stout. Not quite an Imperial stout (my opinion anyway). The aftertaste is where the beer really lives for me. The carbonation distracts the palate from the initial flavors. Then BOOM! the flavors come in full force. All in all, there is no off flavors, well crafted and tasty. This brew is worthy.

Look: Light hazy orange body, 1 finger white soapy head. Smell: Huge citrus (tangerines, lemons, grapefruit peel), apricot, passion fruit sweetness, floral, caramel while warms. Taste: Citrus, passion fruit, lemon grass, apricot fruitiness, mild flowers, caramel sweetness in the background, earthy and resinous hops finishes clean, light bitterness. Feel: Medium-light body, tight fizzy carbonation. Overall: Maine Beer Company found Sculpins little brother and bottles him on the east coast. For being an APA this drinks like an IPA, without the 60 plus IBUs. Very nicely composed hop forward with the malts acting like an unenthused drummer just keeping time. Looks beautiful, smells beautiful, tastes beautiful. Recommended.

Look: Hazy honey golden body , 1/2 finger white soapy head. Smell: Tart citrus, floral, wild wheat grain sweetness, mild earthiness. Taste: Citrus, flowers, tea, peppery dry finish with subtle bitterness. Feel: Light body, tight carbonation. Overall: Very decent brew. This is crisp and refreshing like a pale ale should be. This is well crafted and delicious. This is worthy.

Look: Bright orange body, 1 finger white head. Smell: Dense pine, red papaya, dank floral, sweet cereal grains. Taste: Wet pine, papaya, passion fruit, mild mint, hints of citric rind, smooth clean bitterness, slightly dry finish. Feel: Medium body, bubbly carbonation. Overall: I dont know why I havent review this brew before, but yeah the name says it all. Hop Resin is what this brew contains. The Malt and Hops actually work hand in hand with each other so no one screams "Im the greater". When warms the Tropical notes dominate. This brew is Recommended.

Look: Dark murky brown body, ruby hues, 1 1/2 finger off-white head. Smell: Sweet caramel, earth/pine, pineapple, spices. Taste: Caramel, pine, faint tropical fruits, floral, spices, grass, toasted nuts, finishes semi-dry, lingering bitterness. Feel: Light body, tight carbonation. Overall: I really enjoyed this brew. A nice Amber Ale to watch football with. The only thing I enjoy the least is the mouth feel. It could be more robust but screw it. It is what it is. Nicely balanced between bitter and sweet. A fine brew. Nice, mellow Fall-Winter ale. This brew is recommended.

Look: Black body, Tan frothy 2 1/2 finger head. Smell: Citrus, earthiness, tropical fruits, roast chocolate. Taste: Citrus, tropical fruits, roasted malt, nice semi-dry finish with a chocolate aftertaste and clean bitterness. Feel: Light body, medium carbonation. Overall: My first offering from Maine Beer Company. Will not be my last. Hop forward leaving the malt behind the scene yet enough to add depth. Very tasty. This brew is worthy

Look: cloudy shade of gold, 1 finger white head. Smell: Fruity Belgian yeast notes, deep grape musk, honey, some oak is detectable. Taste: Nice blend between oak and fruity yeast. mild floral, vanilla, faint coconut, honey, hint of banana, alcohol is well covered, nice dry bittersweet finish. Feel: Medium-light body, par carbonation. Overall: Im sorry to see this Monkey leave. The flavor profile is strong but the mouth feel makes it easy to savor. Victory is great at making quality brews, and this one should be added to their portfolio. Recommended.

Look: Nice rich gold body lively carbonation, white head. Smell: Like a generously hopped pale ale. Citrus zest, faint tropical fruits, floral. Taste: Oranges, passion fruit, some grass, spicy herbal tea, in the background, bready malt, very mild bitterness plays on the palate. Feel: Light body, active carbonation. Overall: This pale ale is a to the point brew. It is not aggressively hoppy but it doesnt lack hop flavor or aroma. Pretty well balanced but a bit monotone. Thirst quenching is what really sets this beer off. This brew is worthy.

Look: Black body, 1 1/2 finger deep mocha frothy head. Smell: Huge roasted barley, nice toffee sweetness, espresso hints of oats. Taste: Burnt coffee, sweet roasted malts, smooth chocolate, bittersweet finish, alcohol is not present in the flavor but you can feel the heat. Feel: Almost syrupy smooth body, soft carbonation. Overall: For this being at 10.5%, it is incredibly drinkable to the point that it should be illegal. Smooth body, balanced between bitter and sweet that aches for constant gulps. This is a prime example of what a great Imperial Stout should be. Highly recommended.

Look: Murky shade of copper, white head. Smell: Very fragrant with deep citrus with spice notes, mild flowers, little spruce notes. Taste: Nice blend of oranges and lavender with a touch of pine sap, sweet bread malt backs it up, clean bitterness finishes it up. Feel: Medium body, tight carbonation that tickles the palate. Overall: If I could get this year round, this would be in the fridge at all times. This showcases what Centennial hops are about. One of my favorite single hopped IPAs around. Recommended.

Look: Nice burnt orange with 1 finger off-white head. Smell: Huge tangerine/ mandarin citrus, tropical fruits/ tropical flowers, pineapple (while warms), mild earthiness, spicy, faint alcohol. Taste: Tangerines, mint leaves, passion fruit, more pine needles in the background, alcohol warmth, bitterness builds up yet makes itself known but doesnt leave you with sour face. Feel: Medium light body, velvet carbonation. Overall: There is something special about this beer. Aroma-huge flavor-huge bitterness huge. I didnt get a chance to review this last year (spur of the moment drink). Still is as good, though I remember the aroma last years was more ripe than this years.? Cant wait to see what the 20th anniversary Ruination will be like (if mankind is still alive). Highly recommended.

Look: Beautiful shade of sunset gold, 1 finger white head. Smell: Citrus, pine needles, some spice, lavender. Taste: Sweet malt, then pine resin, little citric acidity, tamed bitterness. Feel: Medium-light body, par carbonation. Overall: This comes off as a single IPA Vs. an IIPA. The flavor is a little let down. For this being an IIPA, nothing really scorches your palate. I do not know the age of this bottle so I can only grade what I have. Might have to go to the brewery and drink on tap. Still worth a try.

I could drink a million of these at a baseball game. I mean for a 4.7abv beer its going to be watery. I find nothing wrong with this brew. This reminds me of Victorys Headwaters, but the aroma is slightly better though. Citrus, resin, herbal tea, cant go wrong. Perfect summer beer. Recommended.

Look: Deep copper, 1/2 finger white head. Smell: Like a pineapple forest surrounded by cedar trees, mild citrus rind, huge toffee notes, faint alcohol. Taste: Pineapples, floral, mild citrus, earthy, smooth bitterness. Feel: Medium/Full body, lively carb. Overall: This brew is worthy
beer_name: Avery The Maharaja Imperial India Pale Ale

review_blob: Look: Honey orange, 2 1/2 finger head. Smell: Mild citrus, floral, earth, tropical fruits (pineapples, mango) herbal tea, honey sweetness. Taste: Floral, tea, grapefruit rind, heat, dry bitter finish. Feel: Medium body, above par carbonation. Overall: The flavor isnt as outstanding as the aroma (atleast for me anyway).  Flavor profile doesnt last long before the bitter bite comes in and screams "Heres Johnny!". I was hoping for more pineapple and mango as the nose tells me.. but I do get a nice long tobacco aftertaste. This brew is worthy.

Look: Dark brown body ruby hues, big soapy 3 finger head. Smell: Roasted malts, metalic, floral, some spices, candi sugar. Smells like a BSDA. Taste: Follows the aroma, spicy yeast, candi sugar, roasted nuts, flowery, slight tart apple, faint alcohol. Feel: Medium body on par carbonation. Overall: I have no problem drinking a 750ml bottle of this. This is balanced, not too yeasty and not too sweet. Even though I like my BSDA to be on the sweeter side, this one doesnt disappoint. Though it doesnt have a "wow factor" it still stands its own ground. This brew is Recommended.

Look: Nice golden amber body, 1/2 finger white head. Smell: Light floral/ citrus, earthy, cracker malt. Taste: Some citrus notes, mild resin, grassy, floral, bready type malt sweetness. Feel: Light body, par carbonation. Overall: Nothing really screams out excellence to me but the appearance. Well filtered, crystal clear. The rest of the brew, even though its balanced, just isnt that interesting. I was hoping for all the hops they used each one would pop and scream on my tounge. This isnt bad, it is a nice beginners IPA. I would drink again more towards summertime. This is worthy.
